title: Broken OAuth leads to change photo profile users .

summaries.content:
This report describes how an API to update a user account photo did not fully authenticate the provided authentication token. This would allow an attacker who gained access to a partial user authentication token through other means to set the user's photo to a malicious image. No feasible method was found for an external attacker to find a partial authentication token, and the flaw was limited to the account photo update endpoint. It would not expose any private data of the user or allow for manipulating files through other endpoints.

**Additional technical details**
Dropbox mobile app authentication tokens have four parts: an app key, app secret, token identifier, and token secret. The first two are shared with all users of the application and released publicly in the mobile application, while the last two are unique per token. The token identifier is intended to refer to a token in non-authentication contexts without giving access to user data, while the token secret should only used by the device when authenticating requests.

The API https://api-content.dropbox.com/r19/account_photo/put validated the token identifier referred to a valid token, but it did not validate the token secret associated with it. This violated the expected behavior of authentication token validation, but it was not feasible to exploit for an external attacker because token identifiers have 80+ bits of entropy and are only found on users' own devices (not through other APIs). A review of other API endpoints found no others that shared this flaw.
